name: Zakir Durumeric
content: Zakir Durumeric Zakir Durumeric Assistant Professor Stanford Computer Science zakir@cs.stanford.edu CoDa W346 | (650) 724-6279 publications | cv | scholar I'm an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University where my research focuses on Internet security, trust, and safety. I am interested in how to protect people against attacks on the Internet ranging from cybercrime and harassment to censorship and disinformation. I am broadly an empiricist: I build systems to measure complex networked ecosystems at scale, which I use to understand real-world behavior, uncover weaknesses and attacks, architect more resilient defenses, and guide public policy. I also founded and am CEO of Censys. Advising and Teaching I lead the Stanford Empirical Security Research Group where I advise: Kimberly Ruth, Agur Adams (co-advised with Phil Levis), Rumaisa Habib, Thea Rossman, Michael Paper (co-advised with David Mazières), and Zimo Chai. Alumni include: Catherine Han, Hans Hanley, Gerry Wan, Liz Izhikevich, Veronica Rivera, Gautam Akiwate, Deepak Kumar, Dolière Francis Somé, Aurore Fass, Paul Flammarion, Manda Tran, Michelina Hanlon, Jack Cable, George Hosono, Fengchen Gong, and Wilson Nguyen. I teach CS155 Computer and Network Security (2019–2025), CS356 Topics in Systems and Network Security (2018–2024), and CS249i The Modern Internet (2021–2025). Open Source Software and Data My work emphasizes creating open source tools and datasets for understanding and protecting the Internet. My team built and maintains the ZMap Toolkit (e.g., ZMap, ZGrab, ZDNS, ZLint, and LZR) and Retina, which are used across the security industry. I architected the Censys measurement platform, which provides researchers with free global data on Internet devices and services. In addition, I maintain ASdb and the downloadable CrUX Top Million Websites.
